reviewText: What more need be said.  Was a great film based on actual events about a couple of heroes fighting against Nazi occupation of Denmark and realizing how easily the lines get blurred.  Realistic and well done!
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: With the drab backcloth of a war torn Denmark after the German occupation in WWII, I wasn't expecting as crisp a picture with rich colors, and generally a very nice Blu-Ray transfer. As the description states, the extra features on the disc are in PAL format, so may not be playable on some TV set ups, although the main feature is region free.The movie can be viewed in Danish, or German with English subtitles.So on to the movie.Despite growing up in Europe, and having an interest in WWII both historically, and in film, I was somewhat ashamed to admit that I knew virtually nothing about the impact of that conflict on countries like Denmark, it always seemed to be just rolled in to a more overview of the annexing of most of Europe at the time.Flame and Citron (based on true events) is a stark, but visually compelling deep, deep drama that manages to be entertaining and informative at the same time.Don't expect wall to wall action, this is more of a smoldering story that even feels like it plods in places, but the tension and drama feel real, even stifling at times.Thure Lindhardt (Many may remember him as the Swiss Guard who gets locked in the vault with Tom Hanks in Angels and Demons) is outstanding playing the 23 year old, fiery red headed Flammen (Flame). He's idealistic, energetic and driven by his love for "Mother Country" to kill the enemy at all costs, but also introspective enough to know he's living on borrowed time, and that the orders he carries out make him at times question his conscience.Mads Mikkelsen (Casino Royale, Clash of the Titans) plays the older Citronen (Citron) , estranged from his wife and child, and so weighed down with the weight of the German occupation, and his resistance dealings, he always seems weary, unkempt, and deeply depressed throughout the movie.Both actors (and indeed the whole cast) are excellent.At a little over 2 hours, some may find it a little to slow and long, but I enjoyed it thoroughly.Although dark in it's depiction of a struggling people under the boot of the Nazi war machine, with local people turning traitors, spies and double agents, betrayal and murder. The film has a personal feel to it. The violence is never stylized or gratuitous, and the strong human story of love and death is well depicted throughout.As a movie going people we need to get over our avoidance of foreign language films, the popular cry of "I'm not paying to READ a movie" is small minded and means that movies like this invariably go straight to DVD, or only get limited releases in theaters, and that's a shame.If you like spy thrillers, drama's or have an interest in WWII movies, this is certainly worth a look. 4 stars
summary: Deep, deep drama - Region Free Blu Ray transfer is impressive
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Yes, it is a foreign subtitled movie, and also a war movie that is not about America saving the world and spreading its Manichean and dubious values and vision of the world.If you can handle that, then you're in for a great movie, a true war movie, where good and bad are relative notions, where there are no heroes but only victims, and where the permanent strugle of human being for survival through their beliefs is greatly captured. Excellent acting throughout, especially for Citron. That is totally a 5 star movie.
summary: Outstanding true war movie, great acting, true story
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The film making. Direction. Acting. When the film ended I felt as if I'd witnessed historyand that these "actors" were the men whose lives have been captured here during the Nazi occupation. Thanks for a film that expands the facts about Nazi terrorism. The film doesn't focus on the Holocaust per se. But as I watched those images, the loss of humanity, and destruction were with me.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I found this a interesting story about a rarely covered theatre of WWII, my wife thought it was just OK and my mother (who is Danish) hated it.She informed me that none of her aunts, who lived through it, ever told her stories about that time that mentioned anything violent happening. I asked her if the fact she was nine might be the reason for that. She still hated it.So the rating is a average.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Based on true events.  This is a raw, gritty tale about two brave 'soldiers' (underground), who, while standing up for what they believe become faced with ethical dilemmas at the same time.  It's an excellent film which will leave you thinking.These men were recognized for their efforts after the war ended.  In the interest of not including any spoilers in this review, I don't want to say more.This Is worth watching ...I had it on my watch list for a while, and when I finally made the time to view it, I was glad that I did.Enjoy!

Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Very well done about a piece of history not many people are aware of. Poses some interesting dilemas we rush past in looking at things as being black or white
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This was an excellent film through and through! "Flammen & Citronen" ("Flame and Citron") from 2008 and directed by Ole Christian Madsen, was set in Nazi-occupied Denmark between, April 1940 - October 1944. It tells the story (based on actual events), of two legendary Danish resistance fighters: 'Flammen' (Thure Lindhart) and 'Citronen' (Mads Mikkelsen from "After the Wedding"), who were no longer certain of the point and purpose of their mission. This film was very honest in its depiction of the brutality of war, but without the glorification of the actions of one side versus the other side. Here the brutality is depicted by both sides (that's unbiased honesty), and it showed us that the so-called enemy wasn't so easy to discern (sometimes they came from your side), like many of the Hollywood-war films would like you to believe! Here loyalties were questioned and tested, as to who can really be trusted during chaotic times like these (even love was tainted). I give the director a lot of credit for having the courage to show, that even the head of the Gestapo in Denmark 'Hoffmann' (Christian Berkel), (one of the characters called him the greatest mass murderer in Denmark), was not a stereotypical embodiment of evil (he actually respected his adversaries, especially 'Flammen'). All in all, this was an excellent film depicting war for what it really is, a hoax and a crime! There are no heroes and winners when humankind is stripped of all humanity for the sake of national pride, or any ideology that condones war and murder!! The entire cast in the film were absolutely fantastic. This is once again proof, that only non-Americans (I have yet to see a film made here to make me think otherwise, with the exception of Francis Ford Coppola's masterpiece "Apocalypse Now" 1979 and Brian de Palma's recent "Redacted" 2007), can make films approaching a discourse that's closer to the truth of the matter. The DVD picture quality by MPI Home Video was excellent. NTSC, Danish Language (English subtitles), NR 136 mins.Love and Peace,Carlos Romero
summary: There Are No Heroes in War...
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: When I found it was about World War II, I wasn't so interested because I have seen many films on that time period.  This movie, however, gives a unique perspective.  It has all you want: a new view, great heros, suspense...
summary: I didn't want to love it
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: One often puts themselves in the place of the characters in movies and in this case living in an occupied country wonders which one you'll be. Of course no one can really know for sure until it happens and we all pray it never happens to us While it certainly is a portrayal of two Danish resistance fighters I think it also casuses you to reflect. It asks the question "is their something in your life that you are willing to fight and even die for, some higher purpose?" Many of the characters were doing their best to ensure their own survival or the survival of their nation, comprimise, betrayal, greed, fear, revenge, justice, and love for country are all on display here. Love for country is often masked for some baser motive in this case. We need heros, they inspire us, but you will certianly see what it takes in this case to be considered one.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Another untold story about unconventional heroes of WWII.  Unfortunately these stories are few and far between, but this excellent noir was well acted all the way around, especially by Thure Lindhardt and Mads Mikkelsen, and it was a story well told.  Worth a look.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: During WWII, two assassins in a Danish resistance group specialize in killing Danish collaborators, but then they include German officers as targets. The Gestapo begins searches and reprisals, a traitor might be in the group, one begins a relationship with a woman who could be a double agent and, as their group is killed or captured, their activities are questioned by higher authorities in the allied war effort. There are no happy endings.This twisty movie is meticulous in recreating the look and atmosphere of Nazi-occupied Denmark. The pacing keeps things moving. Even the quiet moments have tension. We get to know these two men. Thure Lindhardt plays Flammen. Mads Mikkelsen plays Citronen. In real life Flammen was Bent Faurschou-Hviid and Citronen was Jorgen Haagen Schmidt. Both are heroes in Denmark. Both were awarded posthumously the U.S. Medal of Freedom.
summary: Bad people die. Good people die. Loyalty is questioned. Sacrifice happens.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Danes fought a strong resistance against occupation by the Nazis.  Never having heard this epic before, I was struck by the tenacity and resilience of these two men.  They endured persecution and their own emotions to continue the struggle for many years.  Combating such evil that men given too much power commit; this tiny cell of partisans waged a campaign against brutal oppression by Evil and Corrupt men and women representative of overwhelming military and intelligence personnel of the Third Reich.  God Bless them and may their names and deeds never be forgotten nor in vain!
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: EXCELLENT - TWO MEN IN THE RESISTANCE DURING WORLD WAR II - ACTIONTRUE STORY
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Ths excellent film -- supposedly the most expensive ever made in Denmark -- relates what happened in Copenhagen during the last war, when most Danes were happy to keep their heads down and tolerate the Nazi occupiers. Not so Flame and Citron, two resistance fighters who methodically assassinate Danish collaborators on the orders of their boss, who is himself supposedly in touch with the heads of resistance in London. The film is very good at portraying the paranoid atmosphere of a wartime resistance movement, where you can't really trust anyone and are always waiting to be betrayed. The assassins, wonderfully portrayed by two of Denmark's leading actors, start to wonder who they are really working for when the order comes in to kill Flame's girlfriend. To give much more away would ruin the ending of a movie that at times delves too deeply into the murky world of double and treble crossers, but one which is well worth the effort
summary: Really shows you the ambiguities of wartime resistance work
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Well done Dannish movie.  Must watch closely to comprehend.  Overall interesting and provides some background on the WWII resistance in Denmark.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Whew.  This one is a tough movie to watch.  The performances are perfect, and with a true story behind it the movies portrays the very real sense of menace and ego and fear, and the bitter bite of betrayal.
summary: The War You Never Want to Know About
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: FLAME AND CITRON (made for Danish television, originally FLAMMEN OG CITRONEN, in Danish and German, with English subtitles, 2008, 129 minutes) is about two crazy Danes, baby!! Based on their true story, young BENT/Flammen/Flame (Thure Lindhardt) and slightly older JRGEN/Citronen/Citron (Mads Mikkelsen) run about shooting NAZIs. They are superheroes of the Danish resistance. I read about these boys in my local newspaper when I found out that a descendant of one of them lives here.Since this has never been and never will be my area of expertise, let me just observe that this is one heck of a film, quality and drama like few films I've seen. Reminiscent of the venerableArmy of Shadows (The Criterion Collection)(vid. my review), this unusually paced movie brought some thrills that I never thought imaginable. Mostly they did it with incredible camera movement that jars and bounces the viewer to-and-fro in an emotional rollercoaster.Young Flame was the cutie with flaming red hair; Citron (a type of lemon, my dears) looks like a far more handsome, albeit greasy, perpetually sweating Peter Lorre. When they discover that they may have been assassinating innocent people on the orders of their villainous scumbag superior, Winther (Peter Mygind), they realize there IS no reservation for them to leave. They decide to pick and choose their targets from that moment onward.One in particular they want is the Gestapo head in Denmark, Hoffman (Christian Berkel) - the only man who actually seems to respect and admire them. As history apparently tells us, the boys are finally done in when Flame's lover Ketty (Stine Stengade) betrays them. The exciting, heartwrenching and fatalist story of the two heroes is unforgettable. It is just the thing I love: hearing about people who really lived but got unjustly canned by posterity.The color is gorgeous, the locations (Berlin and Copenhagen) are stunning (with some very special effects help) and the cinematography might just start a new fashion - but I haven't seen it properly done except here. The acting is simply splendid: I defy you not to fall in love with either of these necessarily unsavory men. The story is sad and as far as I can determine quite accurate. The two heroes meet an unfortunate but totally expected end.Flame was supposed to run off with Ketty to Stockholm, once he'd assassinated Hoffman; Citron was left by his wife and the only thing he asked was that her paramour be good to them. I guess the theme here is if you're a spy, be ready to surrender family, loved ones, everything. If not, they will do it for you.You cannot miss this, whether you are a fan of WWII films, resistance films, spy films, Danish films or just can't stay away from Mikkelsen movies.
summary: One superhero loused up a dye job, the other sabotaged Citroens
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I liked this movie very much and will watch it again.  I love foreign films and seeing how they portray the same, basic, stuff that our movies do.  It was interesting to see the Scandinavian ideas about WWII.

reviewText: In spite of the limitations of having to follow the movie via the subtitles, this story is well plotted and suspenseful.  I enjoyed it very much. It is also a glimpse into what was happening in the Countries overrun by the Gestapo and how they reacted.

Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: In re-telling the story of Denmark's two top assassins of Nazis, this splendid film turns the spotlight on their private fears, frustrations and personal sacrifices. Beautifully acted.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: FLAMMEN & CITRONEN (FLAME AND CITRON) is a dark long film that will prove to enlighten many about another aspect of WW II we know very little.  Written (with Lars Andersen) and directed by Ole Christian Madsen it unfolds a true story about two 'heroes' of the Holger Danske resistance moment, a large group of Danish citizens who fought to kill not only the Nazi invaders but also the Danish supporters of Hitler's movement: the heroes are Flame (Thure Lindhardt) and Citron (Mads Mikkelsen) and the course of their lives is traced with brilliant use of sound, cinematography, a pervading darkness which serves the story well, and attention to minute details that makes the viewer almost involuntarily involved with their mission, their plight and the final results of their work.In addition to the outstanding performances of Lindhardt and Mikkelsen, there are excellent performances by Christian Berkel as Hoffman, leader of the Gestapo, Stine Stengade as the puzzling spy/counterspy/ love interest Ketty Selmer, and a cast of bit players that remain in mind's eye long after the film is over.  Though produced as an epic (and the film is a very very long 130 minutes!) the interaction between the lead characters is clearly defined and they come across as credible resistance fighters whose plight is always one of duress and fear.As in all stories about war that are honest, there is no clear line between right and wrong, between survival and heroism, and it is to Madsen's credit that he keeps us in the shadows with every encounter.  War is war and it alters everyone who is touched by it.  Grady Harp, May 10
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Very interesting movie.  The style is documentary, and the acting complements it well.  It kept me glued to the TV.The real negative was the awful video quality: low resolution in a small window in the center of the screen. Subtitles we clear though. Just barely watchable.
summary: Great WW2 spy flick: poor video quality.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This film succeeds on many levels. It is lovely to look at, with the gorgeous Danish countryside and majestic city of Copenhagen as settings. It is effective, capturing very clearly what the world must have been like at this time. It is compelling. We sweat and worry and shout and cringe with the lovingly portrayed characters. Those are all good things. They make an entertaining film. But it is more than that as well.There are movies that try to do very little, "exploring" or "suggesting" or other mealy-mouthed words demonstrating that there is no real theme to them. When a movie "explores" the theme of love, I know that people will be in love, but that no particular idea beyond a platitude or two will be discussed. But this movie does an amazing job demonstrating a very easy to state but challenging to convey theme. War is confusing. It is hard to know who is on your side. People lie to their advantage, and when their lives are at stake, they can lie quite convincingly. When nearly everyone is lying, and with a lot to lose, it is challenging to separate the deceitful from the honest. How does one decide who is who? Yet guessing wrong makes you complicit with evil, or dead, or both.Flame and Citron are two idealists who believe they are acting for good. But things are never what they seem, and by the end of this film you will realize just how beautifully this film makes that clear. I don't know if passivity is the answer, but even when you clearly know what the good is, who is working for it and who is working against it is very difficult to identify.And then, to tell us that movements need heroes, even if they're false ones, and conclude the film with the information that these two men were canonized as heroes, well, the irony is perfect. No easy answers here, even when the film is over, but a lovely portrayal of the confusion, anxiety, and exasperation that accompany life in trying times.
summary: Don't miss it; it is both beautiful and confusing
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Streamed the Prime version.  Description said had English subtitles, but none shown on the movie itself.  Watched about 15 minutes of it anyway, and looked like would've been a pretty decent movie to watch.  Too bad.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: A little known episode, at least by this viewer, and a very interesting look at the resistance fighters against the Nazi invaders in Danemark during WWII.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Ole Christian Madsen's "Flame and Citron" equals, to my mind, Melville's mind numbingly powerful "Army of Shadows"--something I had not honestly anticipated.Flame (Bent Faurschou-Hviid) and Citron (Jrgen Haagen Schmith) were the action heroes of Denmark's Resistance to the Nazi Regime and having read about the two of them it is not too hard to understand why.  Infamous for doing what most were both reluctant and terrified to do (actually shooting German soldiers and members of the SS in the street), it seems that it is less the effectiveness of the two men than their bravado and sheer physical courage which is so venerated.  Though in the movie it is haphazardly implied that each had a plan for escape, these plans could have only been very vague. People were tortured and hung for a fraction of what they did and they managed to pull it off for two years. Both were killed in precisely the ways the film depicts in 1944. None other than President Harry Hiroshima Truman presented Flame with a very posthumous Medal of Freedom in 1951.These two heroic and also terrifying individuals are played brilliantly by Thure Lindhardt (Flame, looking every bit Dostoevsky's Raskolnikvov) and Mads Mikkelsen (Citron, the actor's performance as this man tortured by his responsibilities to his family and his unwavering commitment to the Resistance is so powerful as to be frightening at times) are caught in a wretched web of lies and deception no more romantic than a Gothic novelist's version of Fabio going mad.While we are given very little insight in the past of these two, it is obvious that Citron has something to prove about his manhood (the scene in which he tries to reconcile himself with his wife goes to show exactly how the impulse toward violence, however nobly conceived, indelibly stains the human psyche) and that Flame has paternal issues which often disable him from executing authoritative members of the Gestapo who see his youthful weakness and exploit it.The irony is that their superiors talk about "liquidation" in precisely the same terms the Third Reich talked about "liquidation" in terms of massacring Jews.  Madsen's obvious point is driven home with ruthless clarity: at what point does the righteous revolutionary become as bad as the tyrants they rabidly pursue?  Why did these two take little interest in sabotage, perhaps hiding Jews or saving them? The answer may be that since they had no foreknowledge of the Allies winning the war they saw what they were doing as the only possible means: getting rid of the German army and all collaborators one by one before they take over the world?  That is far too simple, and the answer is infinitely more complex and ominous.That old edict, "violence begets violence", is in the end a truth they learn far too late.  The twist in the film which reveals that they have been badly misguided as to who they have been assassinating and leaves nothing for them but horrendous guilt and yet a determination to act on their own.  It seemed pretty obvious to me who was betraying them from the moment the person was introduced into the film, but Flame probably figured he wanted to live as a normal man and not just an assassin at least in one area of his life.  Whatever one's quabbles about their methods, one cannot help but admire the way they go out, just as they lived.  A movie which is a meditation on conscience in a time where right and wrong were discarded like cheap deck of Uno cards.  A masterpiece.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewerName: Johnny Law "not my real name, but still carry...
reviewText: Flame and Citron, the most expensive Danish film ever made (to my knowledge), is a polished .WWII Madsen of a movie, a gleaming production with requisite attention to detail. As other reviews have noted, the characters are not without flaws, and dutifully employed by the actors; Flame particularly crackling, brooding, intense, with the increasingly popular Mads Mikkelsen as his supporting, conflicted, disaffected partner. Key moments in the film are punctuated with dramatic camerawork and snappy timing in the edits; time was clearly spent refining the film, not exhibiting any of the rush-job Hollywood-ism happening stateside. The conflict in Denmark is well-lit here, depicting the split in Nazi reception and the double-agency of taking sides. The history is delivered in a rich, exciting package, with characters which are complex and sympathetic. My only blip if I had to take issue with something, was some truly unbelievable plot concoctions in the later portion of the film. Don't get me wrong; the "fireworks" are impressively done here and only add to the high drama-high action one-two-punch this film's certainly got in its wheelhouse. Just don't expect realism, is all I'd add. But good fun throughout, and well-executed in all caveats!
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Amazing true story of two Danes during WWII working for the Resistance.  Patriotism runs against politics and intrigue by self-serving individuals.  A remarkable tale that must not be forgotten
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: probably watched it on the wrong day. Good subject, poor execution in the translation. six more words requires to meet the minimum review requirement......

Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I really had no preconceived notions going into the Danish film "Flame and Citron." Aside from my knowledge of co-star Mads Mikkelson (frequently seen in U.S. productions, but perhaps most famous stateside for playing the Bond villain in "Casino Royale") and a moderate awareness of the plot, I was a pretty blank slate. Any time you endeavor to produce a fact based epic, there will always be detractors claiming historical inaccuracies. It happens to the best, most well-regarded pictures as narrative films are not documentaries. So I make no claims to the precise balance of historical content versus dramatic license in this biopic based on Danish resistance fighters circa World War Two. I don't know enough to make such a claim valid. I will simply say that from a movie entertainment standpoint, "Flame and Citron" is a thoroughly fascinating, exciting, and riveting drama--one of the best films to catch me unawares in quite some time!In Nazi occupied Denmark, there is a small cell of resistance fighters aligned with Allied forces. Perhaps the most notorious pairing are code-named "Flame" (Thure Lindhardt) and "Citron" (Mikkelson). Instructed and given assignments by their supervisor Winther, the two target only Danes who are collaborating with the Nazis. Lindhardt is the muscle and the more impassioned assassin while Mikkelson largely works in a supporting role. However, the dynamic of the resistance group starts to change. With a potential traitor in their midst, an enigmatic new love interest for Flame, and a peculiar shift in assignments to target actual Germans--something is amiss. But who to trust and to what purpose? The film becomes an increasingly frenzied game of cat-and-mouse in which it seems no one will emerge unscathed.Both Mikkelson and especially Lindhardt provide absolutely riveting performances. Mikkelson's increasing estrangement from his family is powerfully depicted, but Lindhardt is particularly devastating as he starts to question every principle he once held absolute. The supporting roles are well developed with Stine Stengade (as the romantic foil) and Peter Mygind (as the questionable boss) really standing out as well. The film looks terrific--this is a seriously well constructed piece. The screenplay propels the action with believability and true emotional consequence. By the time "Flame and Citron" arrived at its conclusion, I was absolutely mesmerized by the sophistication, smarts, and commitment that went into making this a true epic with historical sweep. Unforgettable leads and a tremendously strong finale make this a personal favorite and a whole-hearted recommendation. KGHarris, 12/10
summary: A Go-For-Broke Historical Epic That Is Entertaining, Moving, And Unforgettable
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I like the story because of the courage under impossible circumstances called for in the life of the main character. The man did what he saw must be done, but that conflicted with who he was as a person of moral standards.
summary: A "profile in courage" with the true human emotions evident.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I have to say that I am not one for war movies, but this film was fantastic.  I was so interesting to see WWII through the eyes of another country other than the U.S.  I was intrigued by the emotion and dedication these characters had.  You can't help but admire how passionately they fought for what they thought was right.  Mads Mikkelsen as Citron was magnificent.  I was so drawn into this inner struggle that I almost lost sight of the greater theme of the movie.  Citron struggles internally with the violent acts he has to see/commit. And, you can see through Mikkelsen's dynamic face and mannerisms how badly Citron yearns to be the good man his family wants, but also the soldier is nation needs.  The film is deep, through-provoking, and just a beautifully directed/acted/written piece of cinema.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: A lot of intrigue. Keeps your interest. Who can you trust? I liked the lead characters. You had to read the subtitles quickly.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: In German and Danish language with English subtitles. Basedon actual events.In 1942, during WWII, a group of resistance fighters wereformed in Copenhagen, Denmark and named "Holger Danske";a group which liquidated traitors and at the same timeattempted to avoid intervention by the Germans. Two ofthe group's most famous members were Jorgen Haagen Scmith"Citron" and Bent Faurschou-Hviid "Flame" whom the Germanseventually sought out for the death of several Nazis."Flame and Citron" is a Danish produced drama and the mostexpensive film made in Denmark thus far. It is directed adeptlyand really captures the essence of Denmark and what it musthave been like during Nazi occupation. The content is takenvery seriously with little in the way of hyperbole and theactors portray their characters with stark realism. The pacingis done very well and maintains ones interest until the veryend. The scripting is also handled very well in this whollypolitical drama, so much in fact that you don't want to missany important dialogue, which is a majority of the film.Being a part of the "Holger Danske" meant living one's lifeon the edge and made maintaining a relationship virtuallyimpossible. The group was twice infiltrated by the Gestaporesulting in the death of 64 of its members. "Flame" and"Citron" however are steadfast in their fight for the democraticstate of their country amidst the Communists and Fascists.Thier loyalty to Denmark is unwaivering, however, they eventuallyfind out that all is not what it seems - deceit and confusionare rampant in war and they quickly realize that they are noexcpetion to these rules.A impressively done war film well worth the rental price andthe purchase price for WWII enthusiasts.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Some people will do morally bankrupt things without any hardship forcing them into it..and then there's what people do when their very lives are at stake. In a time of war, right and wrong - good guys and bad guys can become more subjective notions. Survival,greed,revenge all play a role in this story about two resistance fighters in WWII Denmark, whose solution to fighting Nazis is to kill as many key players as possible. But as a part of an Underground, you have to trust someone. And in the fog of war, it is difficult to decide who is trustworthy and not a threat, and who might sell you out under unpredicted circumstances or even for money. This film does a very good job at conveying the sense of riding the crest of chaos, and getting caught in the undertow of it. An interesting film with a lot of ambiguity to it that will bore many viewers and confuse others. It is not a simple film, and certainly not a documentary. It is mostly about the personal lives and cahllenges of Flame and Citron as they lived in World War II.
summary: The Fog of War and the Definition of "Good Guy"
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: "Flame and Citron" (2008) is a very good and stark movie.The story is about the resistance movement during WWII in Denmark.There are two partner killers from Danish resistance group "Holger Danske" specialized in eliminating Danish collaborators. They face their job with shrewd efficiency and cold blood.Things start to get more complicated due to two different events. Flame meets a mysterious girl, Ketty Selmer, and against all his training he overcome his suspicions and doesn't eliminate her, starting a convoluted relationship.The second event is that the resistance boss, Aksel Winther, charge them to dispose of three German people against all their ordinary modus operandi.From here on everything burst up, some members of the group are captured and executed; a dense climate of suspicion involves everyone. Orders are questioned, motivations are examined and a dreadful sense of not knowing if they are doing the right thing pervades.Director Ole Christian Madsen from the Danish Filmschool has done an excellent work with a perfect timing and constructing very dense atmosphere, at the same time delivering a film full of action and thrill.Jorgen Johansson delivers an excellent cinematography showing why he earned several awards and nominations.The cast, unknown actors and actresses for me, except Christian Berkel, they all give an above standard performance. Believable and sober they flesh their characters with great compromise.I strongly recommend this film!Reviewed by Max Yofre.
summary: The Dark Side of the Moon.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Driven by true events in Danish war history....the screen writers never detracted from the theme and the character casting was excellent.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The facts are that these flame and citron existed and killed people. They really took it out there and they remind me of how bloody the eastern countries resistance movements were, like in poland and yugoslavia.  They are Danish national heroes and they deserve to be. The movie on blu ray looks great and it's subtitled in english. The movie is well done and has a start and ending point which helps in any movie.  It uses first person narration from Flame to explain who is what and what is going on which is fine too.  The story is based on facts and it has them take down several people but it is all taking place in the last part of their story mainly. When they are used by a bad leader and then go on to anger their leadership in Stockholm.  The movie tries to hard to place todays sense of morality into those times.  People were not torn as much by war. You killed people , they died, if you made mistakes you had to just accept it.  The feeling that the real flame and citron were tormented even if they killed the wrong people is probably wrong too. They probably were not happy about it but it was understood by people of the  past that you had to keep it to yourself when in wartime.  There were at least 64 members of flames and citrons group who died during the struggle. Both men engaged in bombings too. So It's probably right to say that this is loosely based on them because the ending is probably some 21st century fabrication. (betrayals etc)Although their final fate isn't in doubt , this movie isn't probably on the level. I wish that movies wouldn't interject todays moralities and antiwar sentiments onto the past. But this is still a good movie because you get a feel for the desperation of resistance fighters who most likely will not survive the war.
summary: good true based story of two resistance fighters
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Not what we wanted, way to dark. Movies about WWII and German occupation are sufficiently morbid without the treatment this movie gave to the subject.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: "Flame and Citron" were the code names of a 2-man team of assassins who worked for the Danish resistance Holger Danske group during World War II. Their real names were Bent Faurschou-Hviid and Jorgen Haagen Schmith. The film takes place primarily in Copenhagen 1944, when the duo targeted Danish collaborators and Danish Nazis. Bent was usually the gunman and Jorgen the driver. Bent (Thure Lindhardt) is a 23-year-old educated and affluent idealist who has chosen to live under an assumed identity, in a basement, and kill people for his country. Jorgen (Mads Mikkelsen) is 10 years older, living on alcohol and pills, growing ever more distant from his wife and young daughter.Flame and Citron go about killing people as if it were everyday business, which it has become for them. They pick up their orders from Aksel Winther (Peter Mygind), go shoot people in the head, and go back into hiding until the next hit list is prepared. They're not killing people; they're killing Nazis. At least that's what they tell themselves. But, as tends to happen in nations occupied and divided by war and ideologies, things get muddy. Bent becomes infatuated with the mysterious Mrs. Ketty Selmer (Stine Stengade), who works for Winther, or for someone else, or for herself. And Winther orders the assassinations of some German Abewahr agents, which provokes a bloody retaliation."Flame and Citron" is a good-looking period drama. It's compelling and, frankly, violent enough that its 2 hours and 20 minutes don't seem too long. The visuals are conventional, and we've all seen countless World War II dramas set in Europe. But these ideas are a little different. Instead of simply heroic fighters and Nazi oppressors, we see an additional layer of people: Those who, for whatever reason, played both sides. Those who were mercenary. Those who took advantage of wartime circumstances to advance themselves unscrupulously. We see that the Resistance often knew about these people but thought it in the best interest of their cause to use them rather than kill them. Politics makes strange bedfellows, often with unintended consequences.Bent, Jorgen, and their comrades, the men taking outrageous risks and doing appalling things for the cause, are subject to the vicissitudes of their commanders and the delicate politics of occupier and occupied. Mads Mikkelsen underplays Jorgen a bit, I think. But Thure Lindhardt is fascinating to watch as Bent, a brave and intelligent young man who would normally have every opportunity for a comfortable and accomplished life, but who, instead, is a killer living dangerously in a world that is impossible for him to comprehend. I don't know how much of "Flame and Citron" has been fictionalized. Both men received honors from the Danish government and the US Congress posthumously. But this film has some interesting things to say about the politics of occupation and collaboration. In Danish and German with optional English, English SDH, and Spanish subtitles. The only bonus feature on the IFC 2010 DVD is a trailer.
summary: Slick World War II Drama with Unusual Insight into the Politics of Occupation & Collaboration.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The start is painfully slow and the dialogue hard to comprehend even to those who understand Danish (due to actors mumbling similar to recent trend in Hollywood!) but the story gains momentum as the 2 Hours ++ movie moves on. It ends up a very decent movie that shows well the situation in the Danish underground movement during 2nd world war, the risks they take and the often unclear and conflicting objectives among the influencial parties in the resistance.Some have personal motives, financial or otherwise, and others various motivations to resist the Nazi occupation and all are only united in their wish to overturn the Germans and free Denmark. Not much unlike the resistance in other more current occupied territories be it Palestine, Iraq or Afghanistan.The actors deliver good performances (not withstanding their mumbling which non Danes are luckily spared) even though highly acclaimed Mads Mikkelsen (James Bond and various other International movies) once again plays his character the same way he seems to play most of his characters - with little facial expression - short mumbling lines in a seeming aim to look tough and slightly troubled.But all in all a very decent movie closer to 4 than 2 stars
summary: Nazi Resistance during 2nd World War come unglued
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: A totally absorbing and disorienting tale about the bravery of some, the cowardice of others, and above all, the fog of war.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I have read extensively about World War II and its many facets - ugly and heroic.  This film falls into the heroic category and is fascinating
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This exciting WWII resistance film is extremely similar to 2006's Black Book.  F&C is a bit more murky than BB and, for that reason, a little tedious in the beginning.  BB has more lavish, Hollywood-style production values but, in general, setting, plot, love interest, murky confusion of good guys and bad guys, and the general moral ambiguity were all so similar that in six months I expect that the two films will be thoroughly confused in my mind.  Both are excellent genre films, if the Nazi occupation genre is to your taste.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The dialogue is in Danish, and the subtitles fly by too fast to fully comprehend.  In general the movie is about Danish patriots killing Germans, without regard for the consequences, i.e., the reprisals by the Wehrmacht or Gestapo who gun down a dozen innocent civilians to avenge the murder of a German officer.  Further lack of realism is provided by Stine Stengard who plays the double timing seductress/spy.  The best actor in the movie is Mads Mikelsen (Citron) although the director strives to make Flame the hero of the scenario.Overall fairly entertaining, definitely not worth watching more than twice.  The best part is the respect the Chief Gestapo officer offers to the remains of our unfortunate heroes.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This  film  describes an operation  of  the  underground  that  was  apparently  based  on  real  events.  It  basically  describes  a  series  of  assassinations  of collaborators  and Nazis in  the  closing  months of  WWII  in  a  grainy,  methodical  manner.  The  filming  is  on  location,  not  smooth  camera  work,  suggesting a  low-budget  documentary  style.  The  acting  is  so-so.  Memorable  mainly  for  its  gory  portrayals  of  the  grim  side  of  war-fare.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: In the interest of full disclosure, I should preface my review by saying that I watched this film on pay-per-view cable, not Blu-ray. Nevertheless, I found this to be a solid and compelling WW2 drama. As a WW2 "buff" I am a bit embarassed to say that I know virtually nothing about the German occupation of Denmark, or that country in general for that matter. This is the true story of the Danish resistance movement, but more specifically the legendary figures of Flame and Citron; two friends who reach the status of underground heroes for their brazen assassinations of German occupiers and Danish collaborators alike. Flame in particular, the soft-spoken, sharp-dressing 23 year-old, manages to become the most hunted man in Denmark. The film is a bit slow and drawn out, but I found it quite suspenseful as the men navigate the treacherous underworld of partisans and Gestapo spies. Friends turn out to be foes, and vice versa, and what spy thriller would be complete without the perfidious seductress who entices our heroic protagonist to his own downfall? The acting and script struck me as most excellent and the cinematography, while simple, was well done also. The brief shots of the Danish countryside were quite lovely, while the majority of the film takes place in the dreary, uniformly gray mass of downtown Copenhagen. This sets a very somber mood for the film. The film is in Danish and German with English subtitles. 4 stars.
summary: Do you remember when they came?
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewerName: R. E. Van Keuren "Bob Van Keuren"
reviewText: Ordinary people had to take it upon themselves to fight against Nazi tyranny in Denmark, even to the point of becoming assassins of Nazi occupiers. Such a necessity does not make the process easy, and just as regular military personnel are changed forever by war, so are civilian combatants.
summary: When someone must act against tyranny
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The plot has been described elsewhere. I will just say this; if you like World War 2 espoinage/resistence thrillers with sporadic action scenes and heavy on plot/suspense you will love this film. Enough twists and turns to make Hitchcock's head spin. The bad Nazi Gestapo guy is an "intellectual" who attempts to reason with Flame in order to bring him to the "dark side" (shades of "Luke, you do not know the power of the dark side" - LOL!!). You literally do not know who to trust, the film draws you in so tightly. AND...just when you think you understand?....the ending shocker hits you in the gut!! The Bluray transfer is great - wonderful blue grey hues for the German army uniforms, jet Black for the SS, etc. LOL!! Being a foreign language film just adds to the realism. My vote for one of the best resistence films EVER MADE!! Highest recommendation!!
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Flame and Citron are 2 legendary resistance heroes of Denmark during World War II. Both actors are great - and I do mean GREAT - but the one who plays Citron (Mads Mikelson) really caught my interest. I searched for other movies that's he has been in and have seen some of them, and have not been disappointed.
summary: Legendary Danish Resistance Heroes of World War II
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This is the story of 2 heroes of the Danish underground in World War II. We could not look away.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: It was a classic movie of resistance fighters of occupation Nazis in WWII. I think it was an example of how two main guys (there were others) who sacrificed to free their country.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Great movie. Very authentic,very good acting and story line. Would watch it again.great location filming, and the cinematography is excellent. 5 stars.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: Excellent WWII Film very well made, Acted and Directed! Film is Foreign with English Subtitles! I don't want to put spoilers but if you want to see "another view" of WWII this is it!
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This is the first Danish movie I've seen, and rates as one of the most powerful in any language. The deep, closer-than-brothers bond between the two men, Citron and Flame, would've been a tremendous challenge for any two actors, and Lindhart and Mikkelson pulled it off beautifully.I use the word 'beautiful' a great deal when describing this film, with reason.I've read many criticisms of this film and it seems to me that many of the critics like to focus on what they perceive as the moral ambiguity pervading the film, its supposed nuanced shades of gray in a genre notorious for its stark and strictly binary Good versus Evil storylines. Sorry, but I don't see the ambiguity others have discerned. Historically, neither Citron nor Flame had any problems whatsoever shooting Nazis and collaborators. Neither would I. And neither, I think, would most moral people with the nerve and the courage to take up that kind of bloody but necessary work. I happen to think the subplot involving the assassination of supposed innocents was made up by the director and the screenwriter since I could find no supporting documentation showing that the two men were deliberately misled on the nature of their targets.Historical discrepancies aside, the two actors portraying Citron and Flame deserve all the accolades they've received for their respective roles. To play Flame, Thure Lindhardt embraced an almost surreal calm, a coolness under pressure that showed without telling why his character was so good at what he did. It grieves me a little in a way that Mads Mikkelson, arguably one of the greatest living actors in any language, has become somewhat typecast as a villain in television and movies. I mean, I'm sure it's good for his career but--based solely the range of his performance in Citron and Flame--Mikkelson could play any character anywhere in anything and do it better than anyone. And then, of course, there's Stine Stengade playing the double/triple agent femme fatale, Ketty Selmer. That character could very easily have devolved into cliched cartoon with a lesser talent, but Stengade brought depth to that role, gave Ketty Selmer a level of complexity that almost made her character sympathetic. Almost.As a last observation, I've fallen in love with the sounds of the Danish language. I've never heard it before, at least not at length, and had no idea that any Germanic language could sound so....I don't know. Melodic maybe?I wish Danes made more movies. If nothing else, I'd watch Danish movies so I could listen to Danes talk to each other. Weird, I know, but there it is.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: The 2008 Danish drama "Flame & Citron" ("Flammen & Citronen") centers on the two real-life resistance fighters in the Nazi-occupied Denmark: Bent Faurschou-Hviid codenamed "Flame" (Thure Lindhardt), and Jrgen Haagen Schmith or "Citron" (Mads Mikkelsen). Like Paul Verhoeven's "Black Book" (very good film from Holland), the story of "Flame & Citron" is told against the background of the occupied European countries during WWII and their people, but the Danish film directed by Ole Christian Madsen relies less on plot twists, though some part of his film looks more like a film noir."Flame & Citron" begins with the muffled voiceovers of Flame, obviously angry, and the real-life footage of German soldiers. The film doesn't spend much time introducing historical facts or the back stories of Flame and Citron. Instead, we are introduced to the ways in which the two fighters carry out their assignments (namely assassinations) directly given by their superior Aksel Winther (Peter Mygind). Both believe in their cause until a series of events happens, which will make them suspect that they actually didn't understand the whole situation about their activities, political or otherwise.Reportedly the most expensive film made in Denmark, "Flame & Citron" offers several action scenes involving gun shooting and explosions, and they are all competently done, but the 130 minute film's true focus is the two main characters Flame and Citron and the tormented psyches as the fighters who start to doubt their activities. Thanks to the superb acting from the cast, and the beautiful, grey-hued photography, "Flame & Citron" remains gripping throughout, though it must be admitted that some plot devices (fictional, I believe) look clichéd, such as the protagonist's estranged wife and Ketty (Stine Stengade) a femme fatale-like figure playing a key role in the second half.Flawed and overlong, "Flame & Citron" is still an absorbing and intense war drama and action.
summary: (3.5 STARS) "Flammen & Citronen": Intense and Absorbing Drama
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewerName: W. Dixon "W. Dixon, Raleigh, NC, USA"
reviewText: Serving country in a spiritual and moral vacuum is captured perfectly in this movie.  Events that manage to capture the brutality without any redeeming understanding of why we did these things in the first place.  I'd have given it one star but the computer said that means "I hate it".  I don't hate it, just don't like it.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: This film (English subtitles) covers the exploits of two young men who were part of a group of Danes resisting German occupation of Denmark by, primarily, killing Danish collaborators, and sometimes branching out to assassinate Germans.  As in all wars, the innocent suffered, both from assassination operations and from German retaliation.  As the group continued to operate, the question arose, and bedeviled especially Citron, whether the leader of the resistance group, allegedly getting instructions from the British, was targeting Danes  who were aware of his business dealings with the enemy.  In addition, someone within the group appeared to be assisting German authorities in exposing group members; the Germans had posted a substantial and ever-increasing reward for Flame, the most notorious of the group.  As might have been anticipated, Flame and Citron came to a bad end.  Perhaps as a consolation, both were posthumously awarded medals.  The traitor apparently received the German bounty for Flame's capture and enjoyed a long and peaceful life after the war.The film was well acted and one got a sense of the humanity of the main characters, motivations and flaws included.  If one is looking for an uplifting film where good triumphs over evil, skip Flame y Citron.  However, if one wants to view aspects of life in an occupied country, it probably hits the mark.  The closing scene provides a glimpse of the costs of war.
summary: Another Film About WWII Based on Fact
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: I think this movie was a pretty good World War II film. However I wonder if the director didn't write Flame & Citron to be too gullible? After all, why would you go to the same safe house and keep the same hideout that the traitors know of? The way their ends were scripted was just too simplistic for my taste. I am sure that WWII assassins were a lot more savvy.
Title: Flame And Citron

reviewText: When I heard about this Danish movie, I was intrigued by its premise of resistance activities against the Nazis in WW II Denmark (a country that is also famous for its rescue of most of its Jewish population from the Nazis). Based on true events, "Flame and Citron" tells the story of two men, Flame (Thure Lindhardt) and Citron (Mads Mikkelsen who also impressed me inAfter the Wedding)who are part of the Copenhagen Resistance Movement against the Nazis. Their primary mission is to kill Danish collaborators and Nazis, be it man or woman, young or old. Their lives are fraught with risks and danger, and this makes it difficult for them to forge any long-lasting relationships. Flame is drawn to a mysterious woman Ketty (Stine Stengade) who claims to also work for the Resistance as a courier and who seems to know quite a bit about Flame. Citron faces domestic problems as he is unable to commit time nor be there when his family needs him. The film explores the moral ambiguities in Flame and Citron's work - yes, the Nazis are bad and the collaborators should be punished, but is murder justified, especially when one isn't absolutely certain of guilt (in the case of collaborators).The bloody nature of their work takes its toll on both men and Flame has moments when he wonders about the morality of what he does - refusing to kill women, and balking from shooting a target who claims not to be a collaborator. It becomes quite apparent that things are not quite as they seem. The story is fast-paced, and there's plenty of action, but at times it does seem that this focus on action and complicated story arcs (double agents, competition between the different factions within the Resistance, etc) detracts from the actual development of the characters. The two leads are credibly portrayed by Thure Lindhardt (Flame) and Mads Mikkelsen (Citron). The cinematography captures the quiet beauty of the Danish landscape, which makes for a startling contrast to the violence portrayed throughout the movie. I'd recommend this to those who like WW II dramas, especially accounts of resistance movements. Also recommended isArmy of Shadows - Criterion Collection, a 1969 movie which offers a grim portrayal of the French Resistance.
summary: The moral ambiguities of resistance fighters in WW II Denmark
Title: Flame And Citron
